@rajinisivaram Thanks for picking this up. Just to clarify, the intent is to handle both when a partition is unavailable (i.e. the leader is unknown), and when the partition (or topic) doesn't exist? By the way, I previously created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4631. Would it make more sense to use that JIRA instead of this one?
@hachikuji Thanks for another round of review and feedback. I submitted an update based on that.
This fixes Kafka-4722 . Will rebase
Re-opening to rebase
Congrats @mjsax !

Is the Jenkins failure possibly related, as I did not see this before:

```
org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.ResetIntegrationTest > testReprocessingFromScratchAfterResetWithIntermediateUserTopic FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: 
    Expected: <[KeyValue(2976621437475, 1), KeyValue(2976621437515, 1), KeyValue(2976621437495, 1), KeyValue(2976621437535, 1), KeyValue(2976621437515, 1), KeyValue(2976621437555, 1), KeyValue(2976621437495, 1), KeyValue(2976621437535, 1), KeyValue(2976621437515, 2), KeyValue(2976621437535, 2), KeyValue(2976621437575, 1), KeyValue(2976621437555, 1), KeyValue(2976621437535, 2), KeyValue(2976621437555, 2), KeyValue(2976621437575, 1), KeyValue(2976621437595, 1), KeyValue(2976621437555, 2), KeyValue(2976621437575, 2), KeyValue(2976621437615, 1), KeyValue(2976621437595, 1), KeyValue(2976621437575, 2), KeyValue(2976621437595, 2), KeyValue(2976621437635, 1), KeyValue(2976621437615, 1), KeyValue(2976621437575, 3), KeyValue(2976621437595, 2), KeyValue(2976621437615, 2), KeyValue(2976621437635, 1), KeyValue(2976621437575, 3), KeyValue(2976621437595, 3), KeyValue(2976621437615, 2), KeyValue(2976621437635, 2), KeyValue(2976621437575, 4), KeyValue(2976621437595, 3), KeyValue(2976621437615, 3), KeyValue(2976621437635, 2), KeyValue(2976621437575, 4), KeyValue(2976621437595, 4), KeyValue(2976621437615, 3), KeyValue(2976621437635, 3)]>
         but: was <[KeyValue(2976621437475, 1), KeyValue(2976621437515, 1), KeyValue(2976621437495, 1), KeyValue(2976621437535, 1), KeyValue(2976621437515, 1), KeyValue(2976621437555, 1), KeyValue(2976621437495, 1), KeyValue(2976621437535, 1), KeyValue(2976621437515, 2), KeyValue(2976621437535, 2), KeyValue(2976621437575, 1), KeyValue(2976621437555, 1), KeyValue(2976621437535, 2), KeyValue(2976621437555, 2), KeyValue(2976621437575, 1), KeyValue(2976621437595, 1), KeyValue(2976621437555, 2), KeyValue(2976621437575, 2), KeyValue(2976621437615, 1), KeyValue(2976621437595, 1), KeyValue(2976621437575, 2), KeyValue(2976621437595, 2), KeyValue(2976621437635, 1), KeyValue(2976621437615, 1), KeyValue(2976621437575, 3), KeyValue(2976621437595, 2), KeyValue(2976621437615, 2), KeyValue(2976621437635, 1), KeyValue(2976621437575, 3), KeyValue(2976621437595, 3), KeyValue(2976621437615, 2), KeyValue(2976621437635, 2), KeyValue(2976621437575, 4), KeyValue(2976621437595, 3), KeyValue(2976621437615, 3), KeyValue(2976621437635, 2), KeyValue(2976621437575, 4), KeyValue(2976621437595, 4)]>
        at org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.assertThat(MatcherAssert.java:20)
        at org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.assertThat(MatcherAssert.java:8)
        at org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.ResetIntegrationTest.testReprocessingFromScratchAfterResetWithIntermediateUserTopic(ResetIntegrationTest.java:200)
```

Seems like a good idea. I might quibble on the using the parameter length restriction though. The alternative is often to use a builder which is a style we haven't fully adopted in the codebase. But perhaps it's fine as a default since we can add additional suppressions if the usage really has no reasonable alternative.

One nit: there's a bunch of unnecessary whitespace in the suppressions file. Maybe we could clean that up on merging?
This is a public API change and requires a KIP: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Kafka+Improvement+Proposals
I'll merge to trunk and fix the unnecessary whitespace in the suppressions file.

cc @ijuma @junrao 

A couple initial points of discussion:

1. Message class hierarchy. The `LogEntry` interface now represents the record set and `LogRecord` represents the record. I have left `Records` with its current name which is a bit weird when you need to write things like `records.entries.records`. I have also been thinking of changing `LogEntry` to `LogRecordSet`, which would make the `Records` name a bit more intuitive. Previously I considered changing `Records` to simply `Log`, though that's a little annoying because of the server class with the same name.
2. The new magic version is implemented in `EosLogEntry` and `EosLogRecord`. This name should be changed of course. Any suggestions? The old magic version is implemented in `OldLogEntry`, so we could call it `NewLogEntry`?
@sharad-develop Can you please fix the rebasing issue? There are 4 PRs with the exact same issue and none of them will be merged (and likely nobody will review them) until this is fixed.

Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

Currently `ConsumerNetworkClient.send()` needs to acquire global lock of `ConumserNetworkClient` in order to enqueue requests. If another thread has called `ConsumerNetworkClient.poll(..)`, that thread may be holding the lock while blocked on `nioSelector.select(ms)`. This causes problem because the user thread which calls `ConsumerNetworkClient.send()` will also block waiting for that `nioSelector.select(ms)` to finish.

One way to address this problem is to use `synchronized (unsent)` to protect access to `ConsumeNetworkClient.unsent` instead of protecting it using a global lock. So that user thread should be able to enqueue requests immediately while another thread is blocked on `nioSelector.select(ms)`.
@hachikuji @becketqin Would you have time to review this patch? This is needed by Add purgeDataBefore() API (KIP-107).

@lindong28 Thanks for the patch. The need for a second lock is a bit unfortunate. I'm wondering if you've considered other options? It seems `send` just needs to be able to enqueue the request safely while another thread is in poll() for this to work. One thought is to replace the map we use for unsent requests with a concurrent collection (e.g. `ConcurrentLinkedQueue`). Looking over the code, some parts might be a little more complex, others less if we did so. But maybe it's a reasonable tradeoff to try and keep the locking simple?
